comment.body:
> [klu9](#comment_1_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Interesting post.
> I have a Huawei E5377 as my LTE modem, and am planning to migrate to Linux in a couple of months. Will that combination work?

E5377 is based on Balong V7R2, which is a bit problematic on Linux. Most probably, it won't be visible in NetworkManager as a network device and may require manual configuration using distributive's native network configuration means.

> [klu9](#comment_2_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Thanks for the info. And sorry for the late reply, I never noticed your response in my feed.

If you want to use E5377 only over Wi-Fi, it will be absolutely fine.
I'd recommend you to choose E5770. Buy it on ebay.co.uk (British eBay), search for "huawei mobile wifi pro". You can easily unlock and flash it.

> [klu9](#comment_4_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Ah, finally found something in English here. So I can access the internet through USB connection to the modem, and there's an optional accessory for ethernet.

Yes. You'll have some problems connecting it via USB, but it's possible.

> [klu9](#comment_3_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): 
> Also I don't think I can use a different modem: the data-only plan I have from my telco has restrictions. I only get unlimited data if I use the SIM in the device they provided, the E5377, and only at my home address. I tried putting the SIM in another device, a phone, and using it elsewhere, but the connection was soon throttled & capped.

Most probably, the operator detects devices by IMEI. Huawei modems allow to clone IMEI after installing custom firmware, that way you can use device you want.
